newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine to test An-70, An-140 early 1997.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine to test An-70, An-140 early 1997.

text.p: Ukraine's Antonov aircraft designer is to complete test versions of two new aircraft this year, opening a new era in the former Soviet republic's aviation industry, a senior official said on Monday.
Viktor Shyshkov, Antonov's deputy head designer, said in an interview that he saw a huge world market for the passenger An-140 and the cargo An-70.
"We will finish the two models by the end of December and start test flights in the first quarter of next year," Shyshkov said, adding that a second An-140 would be ready in early 1997.
Former Soviet airlines have ordered about 200 An-140s for the next two years, Antonov said recently, putting world demand at 600 to 900 planes and domestic demand at 100 planes in the next few years.

Ukraine also has high hopes for exports of the An-70 which experts say will be cheaper than and able to compete with the U.S.Lockheed Hercules C-130 -- widely used to transport Western including NATO, forces and equipment. Antonov says output will reach 24 planes a year.
Antonov blamed human error for the crash of the first prototype, which apparently went out of control and collided with an Antonov plane shadowing it on a test flight in February 1995.
The plane is meant to replace the Ilyushin-76 of the Soviet airforce and the four-propeller An-12. It can carry 35 tonnes for 3,500 km (2,200 miles) without refuelling, designers say.
Funding for the An-70 came from the state budget but Antonov and a Ukrainian-Russian consortium financed the An-140, which carries 52 passengers and 4.9 tonnes of cargo.
The short-haul turbo-prop plane is meant to replace the ageing An-24, widely popular in the former Soviet Union and developing countries worldwide.
"The new plane is twice as good as the An-24. We wanted to design a cheap plane which could get international certification quickly so as to speed up production," Shyshkov said.
In the Soviet era, Ukraine and Russia built more than 3,000 short-range planes, including the An-24 and a cargo version, which now have up to 40 percent of the market, experts say.
"We see a very big international market for the An-140s -- especially in China, Africa and Latin America. But our main customer will definitely be Russia," Shyshkov said.
He said the new plane would suit for remote Russias regions in the North, the Urals, Siberia and the Far East in particular.
"The An-140 is very convenient for such difficult conditions. It does not need proper concrete runaways -- the soil is enough for landings and take-offs," he said.
The new plane's two engines are on top of the wings, keeping them a safe distance from the ground during landings on runways which are in a bad state of repair, he added.

Antonov hopes the new plane will be the first of a family, which will eventually include a cargo version, an executive jet and a 68-seat passenger plane. --Air Cargo Newsroom Tel+44 171 542 7706 Fax +44 171 542 5017
